Now when I have a cold, my senses fade and blur,
The fragrance of hot water, the rustle and the stir
Of blankets drawn around me, a fortress in the night,
A distant world of color dulled to black and white.
Yet in this altered vision, a clarity appears,
I listen to the silence, I measure out my fears.
And when the fever passes, I’ll greet the world once more—
But now when I have a cold, I’m safe behind my door.

My eyelids heavy shutters, my mind a drifting boat,

The world beyond the window is busy, bright, and bold—

Now when I have a cold, I let my body do its best.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
With gentle hands and silent, cunning art,
Unraveled all the dreams I once held true,

The days I counted endless, quick have flown,
Their laughter echoing in distant halls;

He grants in trade a deeper, richer hue;
For though our years may fade, the truths we seek
Will bloom anew in memories we renew.

We anchor hearts in soil and stone,
Longing for a place called 'home.'
Yet somewhere deep, a whisper calls,
To leap beyond these sheltered walls.

For hope is born in restless tides,
In winds that shift, in changing skies.
To settle is to slumber, deep—
But only in the wakeful keep
Does hope unfurl its fragile wing,
And dare us to imagine spring.
